The transcript begins with an introduction by the chair of the committee, Representative Adam Schiff. He introduces the witnesses and explains the purpose of the hearing.

The first witness, Mr. Christopher Mellon, discusses his experience in government and how he became interested in UAPs. He also talks about the importance of understanding UAPs for national security purposes.

Mr. Sean Kirkpatrick then shares his personal experience as a former Navy pilot who encountered a UAP while flying off the coast of Virginia Beach in 2015. He describes the object as being white, oblong, and moving at high speed without any visible means of propulsion.

Mr. Ryan Graves, another former Navy pilot, also testifies about his encounter with a UAP near Virginia Beach in 2014. He describes the object as being white, cylindrical, and hovering above the water before rapidly accelerating away.

Mr. Danny Accoin, a former Air Force intelligence officer, shares his experience investigating UAP incidents during his time at the National Reconnaissance Office (NRO). He emphasizes the need for a centralized repository to collect and analyze data on UAP encounters.

Mr. David Fravor, a former Navy fighter pilot, testifies about his famous encounter with a Tic Tac-shaped UAP off the coast of San Diego in 2004. He describes the object as being white, metallic, and displaying advanced maneuverability capabilities.

Mr. Luis Elizondo, a former Pentagon official who ran the Advanced Aerospace Threat Identification Program (AATIP), discusses the challenges faced by the program in obtaining funding and resources. He also highlights the importance of maintaining a culture of openness within the military to encourage reporting of UAP encounters.

Mr. Ronald Moultrie, the Under Secretary of Defense for Intelligence & Security, acknowledges that there is still much work to be done in understanding UAPs and their potential threats to national security. He commits to working with Congress to address these issues and improve communication between the Department of Defense and other agencies involved in UAP research.

Finally, Mr. Alexander Wendt, the Principal Deputy Director of National Intelligence for Analysis, expresses his support for continued research into UAPs and emphasizes the importance of maintaining a culture of openness within the intelligence community.

In conclusion, the hearing highlights the need for better understanding of UAPs and their potential threats to national security. The witnesses call for improved communication between agencies, increased funding for research, and a centralized repository to collect and analyze data on UAP encounters.

The transcript summarizes the testimony of three witnesses, Commander David Fravor, Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Gresch, and Mr. Chris Mellon, during a hearing on unidentified aerial phenomena (UAPs) held by the House Intelligence Counterterrorism, Counterintelligence, and Counterproliferation Subcommittee on June 17, 2022.

Commander Fravor described his background as an enlisted Marine, Naval Academy graduate, Navy pilot who flew for 18 years, and obtained a Master's degree from the University of Houston. He also discussed his experience with the TIC-TAC UAP incident off Virginia Beach in 2004.

Lieutenant Colonel Gresch stated that he served in the Air Force for 26 years and currently works at the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (NGA). He shared his belief that only about 5% of UAP sightings are reported by pilots and that the government typically does not test advanced weapons systems right next to multi-million dollar jets without informing our pilots.

Mr. Mellon, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intelligence, spoke about his extensive conversations with experts and stated that he believes our government has made contact with intelligent extraterrestrials. He also mentioned that biologics came with some of these recoveries, but could not provide further details due to security reasons.

All three witnesses agreed that there is still much unknown about UAPs and called for more transparency and cooperation between the government and Congress to better understand this phenomenon.

Three military pilots testified about their experiences with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP). They described seeing objects that were stationary, moving slowly, or flying at high speeds.
